summary: Log a warning when observed protocol is more secure than site_url
description: Strange things can happen when FileSender is served via HTTPS but the site_url mentions http. In this case, the user was able to log in but not upload, the error message was terasender_source_file_not_available which of course is not very descriptive. I suggest the following behaviour: If $_SERVER['HTTPS'] && $_SERVER['HTTPS'] != 'off' and site_url does *not* start with https://, then log a warning. The reason for not detecting the opposite, is that the detection may be fooled by a reverse proxy.

summary: Configuration parsing in REST can lead to flags inadvertedly set to false.
description: Referring to r3953, the new code path neglects to read the default values for configuration flags when the user has not provided any configuration flags itself. The system simply returns an empty array in this case, which defaults all flags to "false". This may cause strange surprises when using the REST API and expecting that flags in the configuration file are enforced.

summary: Fix average upload speed counter to work properly after upload resume
description:
Issue: avg. upload speed counter goes berzerk after an upload restart.

Solution: We keep track of the time upload is started or restarted (reset at restart), for each file: got global size and uploaded size. In order to know how fast we go, we take total time it took and do a division. At one point we reset one counter and not the other. Need to know “this transfer is restarting”, need to get sum of offsets, and substract it from speed computation.

summary: Using `createtransfer.php` must check that it runs from the correct user.
description:
When I run createtransfer.php as my own user, I get a lot of the following error message: 
failed to open stream: Permission denied in /usr/local/filesender/filesender-2.0/classes/utils/Logger.class.php on line 353
When I run it as root instead it works, but now I get this error when I try to run FileSender from the webbrowser. This happens because createtransfer.php may create a new logfile, and this new logfile will then be owned by the user that ran createtransfer.php. The following things need to be taken care of: * If log files can't be written, the script should abort. * If log files can be written, they should either be chowned to the webserver, or made group-writeable.

summary: Error message required when HTML5/Terasender upload javascript can no longer read file
description:
Clone from ticket #999.  Need to check what happens when in current 2.0-alpha the file suddenly no longer can be read (for example because it was deleted by the user while uploading).

For details see related (original) ticket #999.

Required for both HTML5 and Tera Sender.

Scenario: start large file upload from USB disk, USB disk unplugges, HTML5 upload script can no longer read file, and upload hangs.

What probably shoudl happen is that when the next chunk of file being uploaded can't be read, after a certain timeout a dialogue ought to pop up "having trouble reading file, cancel upload yes/no?" and maybe even include a "should I try to resume" question. At the very least the user needs to be made aware of the possibility to resume. Most people won't know this and especially for larger files it would be .... annoying.

summary: add option to MyFiles: show which IP address downloaded a file
description:
The current QWA MyFiles shows the dates for when a file was downloaded.  A feature request came in on the feature request forum, by James M: https://filesender.uservoice.com/admin/users/32753502-james-m

It sounds like a good idea to enable this.  It would fit best in the new MyFiles, the one from QWA.  We already have a list of the dates a file is downloaded on, in the expanded view.  The IP address is stored in the database.  So all we need is:
-to display the ip address next to the download date, show ipv4 or ipv6 address 
-implement a config.php switch "show download user ip address in myfiles" to either show or not show download ip addresses in MyFiles

We'll start with IP address, but would be good to have a look at whether resolving the ip address makes sense.  It is a bit tricky, as we don't store the resolving  result in the database, so would mean "live" resolving resulting in possible slower display of MyFiles, not preferable.  Now that I write this, it sounds like a bad idea to do resolving live.  Might be a nice phase2 change for this functionality, with database change to store resolving result "on download".

summary: Make sure invitation voucher upload must *also* always be sent to invitation voucher creator
limit file upload recipient to voucher creator [M]
description:
The voucher issuer can select an option by which the voucher receiver can only sent the file to voucher issuer, i.e. "To:"
= e-mail address of voucher issuer.

An implementation question is whether this is a side-wide decision or a per-voucher-issuer decision.

1. make it a side-wide decision.  A server admin can decide to switch this on, or off.  On means upload invitations can only be used to upload a file to the originator of the invitation.
Off means uploads can be sent to anyone

2. make it a possible choice for the originator of an invitation.  Allow them to tick this as an option when creating an upload invitation.  The option might be ticked by default, or not
(another config option).

If you have a fairly constrained use case (for example to provide a "dump your multi-GB error trace files here" facility to customers of a machine) the first option would fit the bill.

If you'd like to make this the general default but would like to offer users the option to divert (for example: research collaboration of 4 people, of which one (A) has access to a
filesender instance, wanting to enable persons B and C to send a file directly) from the default, we'd need option (2) as well.

Implementation ought to start with option (1), and then proceed with option (2).   Option (2) has UI consequences.

summary: implement auto-refresh after click on download from My Transfers table
description:
implement auto-refresh after click on download in MyTransfers.

This ticket is a clone from ticket #984, remaining work from version 1.6.  

When a user downloads a file via the My Transfer table entry, the download counters do not get incremented until the page is refreshed.  In version 1.6 we did not have a reliable way to detect whether a download was complete or cancelled.  In 2.0 we can detect up to all but  the last chunk whether a download was successfull.

We create an event in the audit trail log for "Recipient X finished downloading <file> (size)" on when sending the last chunk of a download (Etienne, that is correct, right?).

That means we make an assumption in the audit log that afer the last download chuk is sent the file was downloaded.  We may as well refresh the my transfer page when that event occurs in the download case of downloading via my transfers.

summary: Move AuP to be on-first-logon rather then on-every-session

purpose for this ticket: we need to sum up arguments for and against and figure out how on-first-logon can be implemented.  Document this, then make a decision: implement or not.

Idea Chris and Vegard:Set AuP ticked bit in every transaction and just re-use value from the last transaction.  We assume AuP tick is valid until AuP changes. empty-extension.
no-extension

summary: Hanging Flash uploads of large (free memory dependent) files on Mac
description:
Duplicate from versoin 1.5  See related ticket.

When trying to upload files nearing the 2G limit (1900 to 2047 MB) it looks like Flash (?) runs out of memory. With FF the browser crashes, with Opera the progress popup appears but nothing happens (also no network activity). Also Cancel doesn't work and reloading the page will crash Opera also. Selecting a somewhat smaller file (in my case 1536 MB) results with both browsers in a period of disk read activity (and the spinning ball in FF) after which the upload actually starts. 

This looks like Flash (?) tries to read the complete file into memory which may or may not be available. Can this be made less memory hungry? 

Seen on Mac OS 10.5.8 with Flash 10.3.183.5 and FF 3.6.19 and Opera 11.50. MacBook 5.1 with 4G RAM.

summary: Reconsider default limit on #files per transfer
description:
Experience shows a transfer limit of 30 files is not enough.  We need a better reasonable default.  We need to assess whether there is a reason this can't be unlimited.

Practical limits: 
- table of contents in download zip file of 2^64 files (64 bit offset) 
- maximum number of records in SQL table
-most likely a practical limit in the file selection box, probably "over a few 1000" because we would be creating a lot of HTML nodes.  The page would be sloooooow.

Probably not a problem to setting it to 2000, over that may have implications for memory use.

We will configure a default file limit of 2000 per transfer

summary: Bug: size units in upload form: Mb, Gb vs. MB GB
description:
I noticed today the size units in the upload form are now "Mb" and "Gb" for both filesize and upload speed.  However, the average speed seems to be actually expressed in mega_bytes_, not mega_bits_.  

Regarding filesizes: we should be consistent with what operating systems present to users.  And then it's GB and MB
Regarding transfer speed: double-check whether it displays Mbit/s or Mbyte/s.  If it does Mbyte/s the 2nd character (MB/s or GB/s) should be a capital.

summary: Script to send a stats summary by email to site admin
description:
Create a script that sends a summary of key statistics (e.g. numbers of users, upload, downloads, active files and a comparison to previous month) by email to the site admin. Should be institution specific in cases where such information is included with user credentials (will need an additional logs table field).  

Could be done as an optional cron job. Storing parsed data in an additional DB table specifically for this purpose might be best, although all stats can be retrieved from the logs table.

Input Xander: if org-attribuut then instelling = org-attribuut else instelling = domein authuseremail

Implement stats both as email and once queries are settled, implement as "stats" tab.

About access control: lets start with what we concluded in the stats module but without the "user".  
$config['stats_access_level'] = 'statsadmin'; // Who can access stats page. Possible settings are 'statsadmin', 'public' or 'disabled'. A more restrictive setting here would override the access settings below.

To start with the key stats from the stats module are probably useful.  Would be wonderful to have those key stats both per filesender instans and per institution.   Would also be helpful to be able to indicate different timeperiods (up to 10?) you'd like to see next to eachother for easy comparison, for example key stats for 2010-2013, or for march 2012 vs. march 2013, especially when thinking of visiting institutions for marketing purposes etc.

*Note: we do need to discuss the need for anonimisation/aggregation: do we already do this for a simple stats function in 2.0 "asap" or would we postpone it to after we have the key numbers?*  First thought: let us focus on making key numbers per instans and site available ASAP, based on current database tables.  Phase 2: once key stats have stabilised, work out proper way for anonimisation and aggregation, possibly prepared for phase 3: allow sending aggregates/anonimised stats to centralised collector.  Phase 4: pretty pictures.

summary: Bug: Recipient removal breaks audit log
description:
The audit log is supposed to give an overview of what happend to a transfer when and by whom.  

The current audit log is implemented in such a way that it stores identifiers to for example a recipient entry in the recipient table rather than the actual values.  Deleting a recipient leads to dangling identifiers in the audit log.  This again breaks audit log viewing in the web interface and sending the audit log by email.

There are several ways to solve this, not all are equally desirable.  We need to revisit what exactly the audit log shoudl provide as a feature before making a decision.  This ticket will be linked to a feature specification ticket for that reason.

summary: Filename with international characters other than ISO-8859-1 will look 'funny' when downloaded with IE
description:
When using international characters in filenames other than ISO-8859-1 the filename will look 'funny' when downloaded with Internet Explorer and possibly other browsers other than FireFox, Chrome or Safari. The file is however correctly downloaded and usable.  

The "Content-Dispositon" problem

At the moment the labeling of a string as UTF-8 encoded is not done when a file containing special characters is downloaded. The download process uses the HTTP Content-Disposition header with a filename parameter. This header is only defined for filenames containing characters from the (single byte) ISO-8859-1 character set.

Although there are currently ongoing standardisation efforts to make it possible to use other character sets there is no universally adopted way of transmitting a UTF-8 encoded filename yet (see http://greenbytes.de/tech/webdav/draft-ietf-httpbis-content-disp-latest.html for details). The current filesender code therefore relies on what is called 'encoding sniffing' in browsers such as FireFox, Chrome and Safari. Internet Explorer can only handle ISO-8859-1 (single byte) encoded filenames.

See our developer documentation on International_Character_Handling

summary: Handling decomposed unicode in filenames
description:
On (at least) Mac OSX filenames with certain Unicode characters tend to be represented as 'decomposed unicode' (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unicode_equivalence for an explanation). Although FileSender transparantly handles those decomposed characters and leaves the actual handling to the browser and OS it looks like most notably Windows (when storing a file with 'decomposed unicode' characters from FireFox/Chrome) and IE11 (when displaying those files in My Files or a download page) doesn't handle those characters as expected.

We might consider 'fixing' this in FileSender by normalizing 'decomposed unicode' to 'precomposed unicode'. 

Considerations:
- The normalizer_normalize function of the PHP intl extension can be used for this, this requires PHP 5.3+ and adds extra dependencies (php5-intl, libicu)
- Should we normalize when uploading (before storing the filename into the database) or only when displaying/downloading?


This ticket was cloned from the 1.6 milestone: we need to check whether this is still an issue with the current 2.0 code and if it is, whether we can resolve it.

summary: mail bounce handling: decision time
description:
by default, the way filesender sends emails (impersonating the sending user) is not SPF-compliant. Two alternative schemes have been implemented in/around filesender to mitigate the issue.

- one provides SPF compliance using an SRS scheme implemented through EXIM4 and a separate SRS daemon, described here: http://www.assembla.com/wiki/show/file_sender/Configuring_SRS_with_Exim_%28Debian_and_Ubuntu%29

- another reverts to filesender sending emails as itself (omitting the impersonation), and making use of additional code to tag outgoing emails and parse their headers should they bounce, thus enabling filesender to forward any bounces to the sending user. This method is described here: http://www.assembla.com/wiki/show/file_sender/Mail_Bounce_Handling

Both procedures have been tested and are proven to work; I believe it's time to choose one as the default developmental route.

summary: Upload broken by computer sleep mode (it seems)
description:
(theory start)

When uploading a huge file slowly at some point the computer goes to sleep.

That ends up having incomplete chunk upload requests being sent (400 code by apache, php not executed).

After computer awakes the stalled transfer mechanism triggers (no feedback from workers over too long) but transfer cannot be restarted because XSRF token expired.

(theory end)

We need a mechanism able to figure out that nothing happened over more than XSRF token lifetime and refresh said token (not over WS call obviously, more like an hidden iframe in which we load the home page and fetch the token from it, possible since same domain).

This could be an extension of stalled transfer detection.

summary: Javascript errors when using IE
description:
Reported by Lubos Kopecky.

IE shows me error:

Webpage error details

User Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 6.1;
Trident/4.0; SLCC2; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET CLR
3.0.30729; Media Center PC 6.0; .NET4.0C)
Timestamp: Mon, 10 Feb 2014 21:23:12 UTC

Message: Object doesn't support this property or method
Line: 649
Char: 1
Code: 0

Relates to addEventListener not a function in IE - needs to detect if addEventListener is available or replace with attachEvent.This is an IE specific issue.

Code below:
window.addEventListener('keydown', function(e) {(e.keyCode == 27 && 
e.preventDefault())})

Fix: Replace with.
if (window.addEventListener){
    window.addEventListener('keydown', function(e) {(e.keyCode == 27 && 
e.preventDefault())})
} else if (window.attachEvent){
window.attachEvent('onkeydown', function(e) {(e.keyCode == 27 && 
e.preventDefault())})
}

summary: The document root must not contain extraneous files #3.4
Increase update frequency on html5 uploads
description:
Currently the progress bars only update at the end of a chunk. This is extremely undesirable with slow upload speeds as it seems as though no progress is being made for a very long time (especially if the default chunk size is high).

A working solution for this exists only in the context of Mozilla Firefox (Tested 23.0.1) which has full support for using xhr.upload.onprogress events with Javascript web workers.

This solution does not apply to Google Chrome (Tested version 29.0.1547.57 m) which has support for xhr.upload.onprogress events but  NOT in the context of web workers (the event will only fire at the end of a chunk, and no time before).

Solution does not apply to Internet Explorer (Tested on version 10.0.92) which does NOT have support for xhr.upload.onprogress events but DOES have limited support for xhr.onprogress but web workers will still not update this constantly, only at the end of a chunk.

summary: Email formatting sometimes broken: raw email formatting displayed rather than pretty formatted
description:
Test platform terasender.uninett.no/branches/filesender2.0/ is based on Debian with Exim as MTA.  Test platform filesender.uninett.no/beta is based on red hat + postfix as MTA.

terasender platform sends out emails that are displayed correctly at client.  Emails sent from uninett.no/beta are displayed "raw", mangled.  Differences in headers: 

=========
Good email:

--mbnd--alt--1440662171464055dec29b93c0e
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="utf-8"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable


Bad email:

--mbnd--alt--1440520233238455dc982937416
Content-Type: text/plain

Content-Type:text/plain; charset="utf-8"; format=flowed

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

=========

Not encoding the mail as quoted printable by changing utils/Mail.class.php seems to help:

// Encode contents
//        $plain = quoted_printable_encode($plain);


Etienne thinks: mime headers are not being considered by mail client because somehow a double carriage return is introduced.  So quoted printable header is not being interpreted as a header.  Then you get garbled header.  What introduces double carriage returns in stead of single ones as we set in FileSender.

For some reason the outgoing SMTP server might be using old LF character (single \n rather than \r\n).  This can be tested easily.  

Modify file classes/constants GlobalConstants.class.php and remove \r.

If this now works it means SMTP server doesn't use \r\n for new lines, perhaps replaces \r by \n.

Jan to ask Thierry to test this on filesender.uninett.no/beta.

summary: log timestamp - all logging as full timestamp
New and upgrade-proof configuration of database parameters
description:
1.5 adds multiple database backend support (the DBAL code). Initially the configuration was implemented with a single URL-style dsn parameter. For various reasons it was decided to implement this slightly different to both ease packaging and make the upgrade path (from 1.0.1 to 1.5) a bit 'safer'.

In config.php (as distributed): replace all pg_* settings with db_* settings (make the prefix db-independent) and add a db_type parameter

In the code (DBAL.php): check the config settings according to the following flow:

1) check if dsn is defined/set
2) check if db_* parameters + db_type are defined/set
3) check pg_* parameters are defined/set
4) error

For cases 2) and 3) construct a dsn (with possible defaults like host and port if not explicitly set)

This will cater for the case were people still use the 'old' pg_* style settings, will introduce a similar (as in 1.0.1) but more flexible config (db_*) and also allows setting a single dsn for new db-types which need more than the generic db_* settings.

Logon problem with SimpleSAMLphp in different URL space (session.cookie.path)
description:
Behaviour: after logging on a user is simply redirected to the logon page.  Logging of SimpleSAMLphp seems to indicate the user is not logged on, no authenticated session is created.

FileSender 2.0 explicitly sets the session.cookie.path to the site URL on initialisation.  Usually this points to / and won't cause any
issues for the standard setup with simplesamlphp where simplesamlphp is in a separate URL space from
FileSender.

However, on my testing machine and for example for launching our filesender.uninett.no/beta service this
is a bit different and hence sessions between simplesamlphp and filesender are not accepted by filesender.
With Shibboleth this is not an issue as it uses its own session variable handling.  SimpleSAMLphp is in php and shares with PHP.

Agreed solution: introduce a configuration parameter session_cookie_path.  When using SimpleSAMLphp in a URL path other than /, you need to configure this to for example /.  

If the parameter is not set, FileSender uses the default application path which is either specified in site_url or extracted from the application environment.

summary: Shred files to completey remove them when deleted
description:
Submitted by Thijs Kinkhorst

Within our organisation there was the desire that files get not simply unlinked when they are expired but are wiped from disk by overwriting them with random data. This tries to combat the effect of filesender's filestore becoming a goldmine of assorted documents that would be easy to recover - somewhat like the infamous printer hard drives.

Attached patch implements this. The wiping happens at night, so I think usually it will not matter much that it takes a little bit longer than unlinking. I did add a configurable option for it, for sites that don't want this functionality; the default is set to true now because I reasoned that it normally doesn't hurt, and there will probably only be a few sites for which it's necessary to turn it off. Still, I can imagine that you want to pick another default for this.

It makes use of GNU coreutils shred, which I think can safely be assumed to be available given the "Linux" requirement of filesender.

summary: Decide on dropping or keeping config defaults
description:
Currently a number of config options are set by default.  This allows installs to work with a very limited config file but has the disadvantage of "hiding" functionality: stuff just works magically.

We need to decide on:
- what the default set of functionality (and thus config directives) should be
- whether this should be defined in "hidden" defaults
- or whether this should be defined in a sample config file

We need to decide this before the beta, because otherwise an update might break deployed installations.

summary: Alternating My Files table row color breaks sometimes
description:
I noticed that the alternating coloring (white/light grey) of the new My Files table rows is sometimes wrong. It looks like this is related to the number of downloads for some files. How to repeat:
- Have three files in the My Files table, don't download any of them (counters are 0), all table rows are 'white'
- Download the second file in the list one time, reload the My Files page, download counter should be 1, third file now has a light grey background.
- Download the second file again, reload, counter should be 2, all table rows are white again.

It looks like the confusion happens when there is an odd number of downloads somewhere in the list.

summary: IE 10 Compatibility mode script error
description:
When I use an IE 10 with compatibility view activated I can't choose date and neither choose a file. Is it a known bug?
Reported by Iñigo Rodriguez.

Looks like it may be an IE10 Compatibility mode browser issue.

https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedback/details/774078

http://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/12577

IE 10 compativility mode causes a "SCRIPT3: Member not found" script error which stops all scripts.

Without being able to fix the issue in IE we can add 
<meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge"> to the head of index.php and this will force IE to not use compativility mode. Stops the issue happening if someone tries to use IE10-Compatibility mode.

Doesn’t solve the issue of what is really causing the problem which seems to be a browser issue.

summary: Security: check for possible attack using template code in file names
description:
After considering the filename issue that popped out of the 1st security audit (ticket #1173) Etienne wonders about another possible issue: using template code in file names.

As with any other user data we run filenames through html_entities before displaying.  XSS injection and such should be fine.  But we are not running it through template code protection.  An attacker might be able to upload file with a filename containing template compatible code {cfg:databaseword} and do Wrong Stuff like displaying the database password.  Measures to protect against this were implemented in the web interface but not in emails, including the user message.  

Etienne will check whether this is an issue and if needed fix it

If comparing two strings where first string is very large number and second string is also very large number then php will think they are alike.  Lets convert it to integer and make comparison.  Recommendation: always use strict comparison.

Security audit 1: 2.14.4: Usage of variable variables
description:
*Issue:* _defence in depth:_ the "variable variables" technique is used in the template parser where variables are dynamically created.  This may lead to a situation where a user can overwrite any variable in the current symbol table like a path variable and include a php script controlled by the user like a php script included in a URL.  At the moment this is not exploitable as the user doesn't control the keys that are provided with the vars parameter.   In future versions this might change. 

Pine recommends to switch to a different mechanism like a key/value store.

*Assessment:* This is currently not a problem as there is no flow that allows a user to call the template method.  Implementing a  key/value store approach makes writing templates heavier.  For the time being we will keep this as it is and gather practical experience with the template mechanism.

Details: In the template class there's a method that when called renders a template.  This method looks for a template, resolves the template path (is it in the config directory because it's a customised template or is it in the default template directory?).  Then it includes that template file if found while creating on the fly a set of varilables that the template will use.  The method is given an associated array of key-value pairs (foo=bar) and creates variables for use in the template with name 'foo' and value 'bar'.     .  It could become

issue confirmed and needs to be addressed.  Using a key/value store approach makes writing templates heavier.  Hesitating between rewrite using some kind of keystore or filtering given variables before creating variables so they don't contain unexpected stuff like globals etc., path variable.  The latter approach is error-prone, every time we introduce variable we also need to update the filter.

When rendering for example a report at end of upload, the template process method with template name "report" can have a variable report=array of report objects.  In template code this then allows for a construct like "foreach $report as report do ....".  

This mechanism is to make for easier template writing.   It is currently not directly exploitable and needs significant other bad programming practice to make this exploitable. 

A possible future exploit: if at some point user input is fed directly to the template processing function, it could give a set of variables that could have post data.

*Response:* this is not exploitable and needs significant bad programming practice to make it exploitable.  We will gain practical experience with the template mechanism to see if the balance ease of use vs. security in depth needs to be different in future versions.

summary: Security audit 1: 2.14.2: PHP object injection
description:
*Issue:* _defence in depth:_ when an exception occurs a user is redirected to a page with a serialised array containing information about the exception.  This array is unserialised and used to generate an exception object.  User input can be used when serialising and unserialising arrays.  A user can also give the application an object in this way; the application will happily unserialise object upon which the PHP interpreter will automatically call several functions on that object, e.g. wakeup, destruct, etc.   This has an unknown impact on application.  At the moment this can not be exploited but it might be exploitable in future FileSender versions.  For defense-in-depth this should be addressed.

*Assessment:*	issue confirmed. This can not be exploited now  as there is no code like wakeup or destruct that does anything when called but this might become a problem in the future.  This will be addressed by using JSON.  Daan agrees this is a good solution.

*Response:* json serialisation will be used to avoid potential code injection when using native serialise/unserialise.

summary: Security audit 1: 2.11.8: Anti-clickjacking measures must be implemented
description:
*Issue:* _vulnerability:_ there is no protection against click-jacking nor do we mention clickjacking as a risk anywhere in the installation documentation.  Recommendation is to set the x-frame-header in each request or same-origin, allow-from in the webserver config and/or document in the manual what to do if iframes are allowed.  Either we document the risks with using iframes or ensure they can't be used.

*Assessment*: this is both a risk and a feature.  Integrating FileSender using an iframe is a feature.  Should you want to limit inclusion of FileSender in iframes, preliminary investigation suggests W3C's candidate recommendation Content Security Policy (CSP, http://www.w3.org/TR/CSP2/) is the standards-based way to do this.  According to http://caniuse.com/#feat=contentsecuritypolicy this is supported on most currrent browsers.  IE11 is supported by adding X-Content-Security-Policy. Daan suggests to set the same-origin header in the Apache config.   

*Response*: as this is both a feature and a vulnerability we will not enforce this in the FileSender application.  We will use CSP to allow for fine-grained protection.  Rather than implement a swath of config options in FileSender we will document how to configure CSP in Apache for use with FileSender to prevent inclusion in iframes.

summary: Feature: maintenance mode
description:
This allows to interrupt the service for database upgrade or even server restart without breaking uploads.

When switched on:

  - all pages are replaced with the maintenance page
  - webservice returns specific exception to all requests
  - clients display a popup explaining what happens
  - clients pause uploads and put all requests they were about to make in a stack
  - clients starts to query the server on a regular basis to see if maintenance ended (server responding with no exception status)
  - when server exits maintenance mode clients restart uploading and run stacked requests and remove maintenance popup

Implemented in changeset [[3431]] and  [[r:3534]]

Config directive is config parameter "maintenance" that is boolean and false by default.

summary: Ensure ZIP files work with most common clients
description:
The ZIP files produced by Zipper.php don't currently work with the Mac OS X Archive Utility. Depending on the value of the "version needed to extract" header that is sent with the file, one of two behaviours occurs:

* The .zip file unzips to a .cpgz file, which unzips to a .zip file, which unzips to a .cpgz file, and so on (see [[url:http://linlog.skepticats.com/entries/2012/02/Streaming_ZIP_files_in_PHP.php|here]]).
* An error message is produced: _Error 2: No such file or directory_

The unzip terminal command appears to work without reporting any errors.

We also need to test the files with other common clients. In Windows 7 (x64), both the default Windows Explorer utility and WinRAR are able to handle the files. In Ubuntu 13.04 (x64), the unzip terminal command works fine.

description:

summary: Securit audit 1: 2.7.1: User input must be encoded in the context where it is used
description:
*Issue:* _defence in depth:_ when FileSender receives user input the function sanitizeInput is used to ensure the input will not contain anything that will be executed.  This function currently filters the input for a number of dangerous characters and adds a space to them. Pine recommends to use escaping, the current code uses filtering.

Filtering changes the input and might lead to unexpected side-effects.

*Assessment*: Etienne's collegues in the Sympa mailinglist software project had a security audit executed where an issue was found using variable encoded string injection.  The offending string had to be machine-generated.  This string defeated perls regexp-based entity encoding mechanism.  The php mechanism behaved the same.  Sympa introduced a filtering fix which was reported in this FileSender audit.  
The filtering fix was based on a blog-article published on OWASP as a recommendation.  Unfortunately the blog article is now no longer accessible. 

Daan indicated he's unaware of any technique to bypass html_entities.  He tested by removing the line of code and injection of code was not possible.  The strong recommendation is to not filter on input; you don't know where the data will be used.

*Response:* there is not yet consensus in the FileSender core team on the best approach.  Based on the experience of the Sympa mailinglist software team escaping alone might not be enough.  The issue found in the Sympa security audit might now have been fixed and the filtering fix no longer needed.  We will await the results of the 2nd security audit and then decide what to do.  We will address this before the 2.0 release.

summary: Security audit 1: 2.6.13: Generated passwords and tokens must not be predictable
description:
*Issue:* vulnerability: FileSender uses random numbers and identifiers in various places, for example in the download URL.  The reviewd 2.0 codebase uses uniq_id and mt_rand.  Both don't return a sufficiently secure random number which may result in an attacker guessing the state of the random generator.  An attacker might thus be able to guess download URLs and CSRF tokens.  Recommend to use secure random generator.

*Assessment:* Issue confirmed and needs to be addressed before the 2.0 release.  Preferably without using openssl as it would add a dependency and be about 100 times (ballpark figure)  slower than using the other random generator.

The unique identifiers used in FileSender need to have two characteristics:
•	the ID must be unique
•	the ID must be non-guessable.  As long as you can't guess the random number in the ID you can't guess the random generator state.  

For the FileUID we check uniqueness, if a collision occurs we generate a new one.   To make the ID non-guessable Pine recommends a HMAC.  The recommendation is to use a secure random number generator like openssl but using for example /dev/urandom or mtrand and hash that combined with a salt value to an HMAC is sufficiently secure.  FileSender would need to auto-generate the salt value.

Pine comments that wile an attacker in this way won't be able to directly know the random number you have to be very careful you don't leak random number to user somewhere. 

*Response:*  Etienne will add HMAC with a random generated salt and look at making it configurable to read urandom or use mt_rand.

This will happen when: - a customised config/locale.php does *NOT* contain a mapping for en-au - $config['site_defaultlanguage'] is either "en_AU" or not defined - none of the language tags sent by the browser is found in the customised config/locale.php The 'error' here is that the en-au => en_AU.php mapping is not present in the customised config/locale.php Stricty speaking this shouldn't be an error since in all cases FileSender will use the default en_AU.php definitions. The specific error message is meant to detect for example a missing mapping when $config['site_defaultlanguage'] is *not* "en_AU" and the corresponding mapping in locale.php is missing.

summary: A chunk was sent after transfer complete resulting in an error
description:
Symptom: the upload succeeds, mails are sent, but there is still an error both to user + in the logs on server side.

Upload of a 5GB file on terasender.uninett.no/branches/filesender-2.0/  The upload was with Safari.  That instance is now configured with 6 webworkers.  I did the upload over the WLAN.

A couple of times the message was displayed "slower than usual, try again, quit etc.".  I clicked try again, it hopped a bit back in
progress and the progressed.

At the end, the progress bar indicated the upload was complete, I got the download email, and I got an error (enclosed in this mail)
that there was a problem.

In the logs server side I can see there's a problem logged.

On disk the file appears to be all there:
-rw-r--r--  1 www-data www-data 5368710144 Feb  9 11:35 397b17f7-bccf-a1d8-c600-41d72a7ca092

It also downloads again:
-rw-r--r--@   1 meijer  staff  5368710144 Feb  9 11:18 testfile-5GB+1byte-2.dat

Etienne's analysis:

* When last worker finishes: triggers file complete request.  When all files are complete, transfer complete request is sent.  Normally triggers mail sending etc.
* After this transfer complete request was sent another chunk was sent.  The webservice doesn’t accept chunks after a transfer complete is sent.  the client should NOT send chunks after transfer complete.
* this MAY happen in one case only, with the automatic restart of stalled transfers.
* There are TWO automatic restarts of a transfer before asking whether a transfer should restart so a user won't see if a transfer restarts only once

There might be a situation where the transfer is both complete and restarted.  Etienne will add more logging to see if restarts have an unfortunate timing.

This is a bug we need to fix.

summary: Document $config['stalling_detection']
description:
file_sender > 3954

Authored by etiennemeleard
Parent: 3953
2016-06-07 09:47
Allow to configure client stalling detection.

Related config parameter is "stalling_detection", it may be :

- A true boolean to enable detection with default behaviour :
$config['stalling_detection'] = true;

- An array including any of the following values (all optional) :
count_divergence : the maximum chunk count a worker can be late over the global average (last 5 chunks of every worker)
duration_divergence : the maximum ratio between a process's current upload time and the global average (last 5 chunks of every worker)
automatic_retries : the number of times the upload is resumed transparently before asking the user if he/she wants to keep going

Full version is (those are also the default values) :

$config['stalling_detection'] = array(
'count_divergence' => 10,
'duration_divergence' => 7,
'automatic_retries' => 3
);

- A false boolean to turn off detection :
$config['stalling_detection'] = false;

summary: FireFox upload hangs with 30 workers
description:
If you set the number of webworkers to be used to 30, uploading works fine with Safari and Chrome, but not with FireFox.  Confirmed on UNINETT and DeIC 2.0 test install.  Symptom: just nothing happens and nothing is logged.

Set the number of workers to 16 and it also works with FireFox.

Etienne provides following feedback:

The mechanism in a terasender upload is as follows:
- a worker requests a job with the terasender job driver
- the job driver locks (sets boolean in itself) so it doesn't respond to multiple workers.  If another worker tries to access it it tells the other worker to wait.  This ensures no chunk is given to two workers.
- the driver gives a worker an answer; either "here is a chunk for you" or "nothing more to do".

if this messaging mechanism breaks down nothing will work.

Thoughts:
- maybe past a certain number of workers with each worker waiting for .5 seconds, with a lot of workers it may be just waiting?
- maybe there's some overflow in the messaging system in FireFox?
- upon checking the upload console: every worker is requesting a job.  First worker is given file, other worker gets “nothing to do” as a response.  Are expected to close.  First worker doesn’t even signal worker is complete.  Past specific number of workers the browser starts to handle events in a bad way.
-Is the bug related to max number of workers or to large number of workers combined with async uplods?
-what is the breaking number?  
-maybe there is a limit in the global amount of “work” FireFox can do?  That Safari and Chrome doesn’t have?  Does messaging just break down?

Etienne will take following actions:
- test to see if there is a specific fixed breaking point in # webworkers
- check Mozilla email list for similar issues and write email asking others if they've seen similar things
- post on Stack overflow

This is not a high priority issue at the moment: just don't set the #webworkers to 30 does the trick.  But we need to figure out what causes this.  If it's a firefox bug it should be fixed.  If it is some issue in our code it should be fixed.  

For the 2.0-alpha we will -unless we find out what causes it- label this as a known issue for now.

summary: database creation script improvement suggestion for version 0.1.3
description:
Date: Thu, 22 Oct 2009 15:46:40 +0200
From: Hans Zandbelt <hans.zandbelt@surfnet.nl>
Reply-To: filesender-dev@filesender.org
To: filesender-dev@filesender.org
Subject: [filesender-dev] [feature] version 0.1.3 database creation script

Hi,

Can I suggest to drop te "WITH (OIDS=FALSE)" clause from the
table creation statements?

It seems to be incompatibile with PostgreSQL 8.1.18 which comes with
Redhat Enterprise Linux 5.4; above that there's also a "default_with_oids"
configuration parameter which sorts it out for newer installations on
a system level.

This way at least the PostgreSQL version requirement can be narrowed
down from "latest version" to ">= 8.1.18".

Regards,

Hans.

-- 
Hans Zandbelt                    hans.zandbelt@surfnet.nl
SURFnet                             http://www.surfnet.nl

--- filesender_db.sql.org       2009-10-19 11:43:00.000000000 +0200

@@ -18,8 +18,7 @@
   fileexpirydate timestamp without time zone,
   fileactivitydate timestamp without time zone,
   CONSTRAINT files_pkey PRIMARY KEY (fileid)
-)
-WITH (OIDS=FALSE);
+);
 ALTER TABLE files OWNER TO postgres;
 GRANT ALL ON TABLE files TO postgres;
 GRANT ALL ON TABLE files TO public;
@@ -58,6 +57,5 @@
   logmessage text,
   logvoucheruid character varying(60),
   CONSTRAINT logs_pkey PRIMARY KEY (logid)
-)
-WITH (OIDS=FALSE);
-ALTER TABLE logs OWNER TO postgres;
\ No newline at end of file

summary: PDO rowCount Query Fixes

In several places PDOStatement::rowCount was used with a SELECT statement.
This seems to work OK for Posgres and MySQL, but it does not for SQLite.
From http://php.net/manual/en/pdostatement.rowcount.php:

"For most databases, PDOStatement::rowCount() does not return the
number of rows affected by a SELECT statement. Instead, use
PDO::query() to issue a SELECT COUNT(*) statement with the same
predicates as your intended SELECT statement, then use
PDOStatement::fetchColumn() to retrieve the number of rows that will
be returned."

Pause / Resume on (Multi)file Uploads
description:
'Pause/Resume' 'Suspend' and 'Cancel' buttons need to be added to the progress bar dialog box.

Pause should *temporarily* stop the uploading of files until the user chooses to resume them (via the same button). Using this will *not* allow the user to resume after leaving this page and is used to relieve the users bandwidth temporarily.

Suspend should make it possible for users to stray away from the transaction and continue it as part of another session, this would be an explicit version of the pause/resume functionality which is currently in place. Users should be warned after choosing 'suspend' of how it works and the steps required to come back to this transaction. This should be paired with functionality which tells users they have a pending upload transaction and should continue to ask them if they wish to either continue with the upload or cancel it. 
This will only work when the user uses the same browser&computer combination to resume the upload.
Some way, for example via a button/dropdown list/dialog for the user to access a list of their suspended transactions. This stops the user from having to repopulate the list themselves and would essentially make the uploads page re-appear how they left if (any file uploads complete in that transaction would still be there with complete progress bars). Suspended transactions should have some form of expiration date. Requires validations/error checks to ensure the pending files still exist on disk.

Cancel should forfeit the transaction and stop *all* files (both those already finished and those in the queue). Downloads do not have to be paused to be cancelled, but a warning 'are you sure?' should be provided.

This transfer option can not be set in the UI, it needs to be set with an API call.

The use case is using a separate FileSender service to upload big files to a digital exam system.
* a student uses a digital exam to hand in an exam
* the student wants to attach a file to the exam system by way of an external filesender service
* on clicking the "attach big file" link the digital exam system creates a guest voucher for that particular student/exam session and redirects the user to the guest invitation URL.  In the guest invitation the transfer option "redirect_url_on_upload_complete" is set to the digital exam system
* the user uploads the file, on upload complete the user is redirected back to the digital exam system
* the digital exam system downloads the file to its own repository

summary: Find alternatives to OpenIdP accounts
milestone: Release 2.0: Adapt project processes to version 2.0 reality
description:
OpenIdP will be phased out per 1 January 2016.  I've verified internally at UNINETT that the entire OpenIdP service will disappear, it also will not be accessible for me as a UNINETT employee.  AFAIK there are no current alternatives available that do the exact same.

The FileSender project uses openidp.feide.no as an IdP for the following purposes:

1. test accounts for (automated, selenium-based) client-side testing.
2. ensuring federated login is tested before we release 
3. as the default IdP new FileSender installations can authenticate against.  This ensures the 1-hour setup time.
4. as a self-registration user account system for demo (test) instances

Considerations with the purpose 1, use for test accounts:
- the credentials need to be able to be exposed to external services without problems, like selenium service providers.  Credential exposure should not lead to possible compromise of other services
- we need to be able to specify which email addresses are associated with the test accounts

Considerations with purpose 3, use by new FileSender instances to test their installation
- no default username/password should be distributed with a FileSender release

We will need to find a (combination of) alternative(s).

summary: Add documentation for bounce handling (general explain + config directive)
description:
Add feedback email handling script and bounce handling related default config.

Script can be called as :
    
    php cron/emailfeedback.php [options] [sources]
    
    options are :
      * --remove_after_processing : remove file after processing
      * --move_after_processing[=target] : move file to target folder after processing, if no absolute target will be considered to be under source folder, if no target given "done" source subfolder
is used by default
    
    sources can be (several may be used at the same time) :
      * a path to a file containing a rfc822 message
      * a path to a folder containing rfc822 message files
      * - to get rfc822 message from standard input
    
    if no sources are defined standard input is used by default

New config parameters related to bounce handling :

report_bounces, bounces reporting mode, possible values are :
  - null / false / 0 : bounce reporting disabled (bounces are still saved and displayed in ui, just not reported by email)
  - asap : report every bounce right away (default)
  - daily : compile a daily report for each transfer/guest (handled by cron/cron.php)
  - asap_then_daily : bounces in a time range (see report_bounces_asap_then_daily_range) after transfer/guest creation are reported right away, bounces comming after are reported daily

report_bounces_asap_then_daily_range, time range for asap reporting in asap_then_daily bounce reporting mode, in seconds, defaults to 15 minutes

summary: Document access web service as remote user (!= remote application)
description:
Add to general API documentation (?) and config directives if needed.

"Add a way to use webservice as a remote user (!= remote application).

It must be enabled using the auth_remote_user_enabled configuration parameter (boolean, false by default).

It uses a signed request (same as remote applications), the only difference is that each user have its own secret (stored as a preference).

Secrets can be automatically generated by setting auth_remote_user_autogenerate_secret configuration parameter to true (false by default).

It will allow to setup per-user based trust relationships between a filesender instance and other, potentially non-web based, applications.

Use case is a Thunderbird plugin which allows to put big files on filesender, user installs the plugin and give its secret to it, then the plugin can upload files on behalf of the user.

Sample php client has been updated to be able to use either remote application or remote user authentication.

Changeset alert by etiennemeleard in project FileSender 

.............................................................................

Adding an option to get a link for download instead of sending to recipient (disabled by default).

When using this an anonymous recipient is created (that is, without email) and its download link is given back to the uploader at the end of upload.

When using this option the user can embbed the link in any mail of his choice (newsletter for example), all downloads are obviously counted as done by the single anonymous recipient.

This mode will be helpful for people wanting to use their FileSender server from another application (like big attachments handling in mail clients).

This option must be enabled in the transfer_options configuration associative array under the name get_a_link (advanced mode is ignored as well as default).

Also adding user id in user page (if enabled).

They still work on the FileSender 1.6 code though.  That seems to indicate it's not directly related to the terasender upload code.  I do remember Jack implemented a new way for processing progress events from web workers in 2.0. summary: Admin: maintenance mode
description:
This allows to interrupt the service for database upgrade or even server restart without breaking uploads.

When switched on:
  - all pages are replaced with the maintenance page
  - webservice returns specific exception to all requests
  - clients display a popup explaining what happens
  - clients pause uploads and put all requests they were about to make in a stack
  - clients starts to query the server on a regular basis to see if maintenance ended (server responding with no exception status)
  - when server exits maintenance mode clients restart uploading and run stacked requests and remove maintenance popup

Config directive is config parameter "maintenance" that is boolean and false by default.

implemented in ticket #1182.

summary: Modify session validity check on upload to allow for very long uploads
description:
Currently FileSender checks for each chunk whether the user has a login session at the IdP.  This is unfortunate as the IdP controls when that session times out.  Experience from the Norwegian install show that uploads lasting longer than 8 hours suffer from session timeout at the IdP: the Norwegian identity federation IdP has a timeout after 8 hours.

There are several factors in SimpleSAMLphp that the SP controls but one it doesn't:  SessionNotOnOrAfter is sent in the SAML response from IdP to SP.  Olav Morken writes:

" It is also sent from the IdP to the SP, in the
      "SessionNotOnOrAfter" attribute. The SP is supposed to use this
      to determine when the session expires. In practice, this means
      that the IdP can force the SP to reauthenticate more often than
      whatever the SP has set in 'session.duration'. "

https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups=#!topic/simplesamlphp/ERlbkoFpntw

It's the SessionNotOnOrAfter that bites us.  The implication is that when a FileSender upload lasts longer than SessionNotOnOrAfter ( 8 hours in Norway) the user gets a "you're no longer authenticated" message.  

A solution is to change how FileSender deals with this: define a FileSender valid upload session, that remains valid for as long as an upload runs.  Only *after* the upload is completed will the IdP be asked again whether the user still has a valid session.  This means an upload will complete and should the user want to upload another file, a new session needs to be established if the old one has expired.

A big advantage with pulling control over upload session validity into FileSender.  Xander reports this should not be too complicated.

Xander's list of points of consideration:
- be aware of session hijacking etc.  The "FileSender valid upload session" should only be valid for a specific browser/client upload that started after normal authentication.  Probably a combination of sessionId and unique upload token (something we already have?)
- such an upload token needs its own expiry, e.g. if 15 minutes without a new chunk then lose validity as AuthN token
- what to do with the combination uploadcomplete and timedout SSP-session?  We need to present "your upload has completed" page.

xander, please check the description and modify where needed.

summary: Minimise FileSender data privacy footprint
description:
With the Snowden revelations fresh in mind FileSender allows any person or organisation using it to subject its data to only the intelligence organisations of it's choosing.  Following well established engineering principles "what isn't there can't be abused" FileSender ought to be optimised to minimise the data privacy footprint of its users.  This also minimises possible exposure in case a FileSender instance should be compromised.  

This means logging least possible, by default deleting possibly sensitive logging in a timely fashion and in general ensure FileSender admins don't have (easy) access to privacy sensitive information.  It also means deleting privacy sensitive entries from the database, either by anonimising the privacy sensitive bits (like we did in the stats module) or by deleting them.

In particular we need to remove data that details communication meta-data: who sends what to whom.  It's probably OK to have such an overview on the institutional/domain level, but not on personal level.  When should it be purged?  After expire of the file/transaction or based on a time limit?  What about the audit trail?  Once purged, the audit trail disappears.  How does this work with the database being backup-ed?  What about sending the audit trail as an email to the sender?  What about making an "incognito" transaction? 

A number of FileSender features depend on having historical data available:
-auto-complete in the To: field
-the audit trail for a sender of a file, especially in the cases where the user chose to not receive emails of the file downloads
-other?

The audit trail might be an important one, with anecdotal evidence and logging suggesting a number of users use FileSender in particular for the email receipts.  A straight forward solution is to simply gather the audit trail in an email and send it to the sender of the file on purge of the record.  That way the audit trail is where it belongs (transaction owner) and it's not with us.

We need to think this through carefully but do need to address it in our 2.0 release.  We also need to check up on the EU plans on the data privacy directive update that's underway now, it would be great to already be fully compliant :)

Comments are very much appreciated.

summary: Establish policy for dealing with known issues
milestone: Release 2.0: Adapt project processes to version 2.0 reality
description:
With every release we have had and will have known issues: stuff we know is broken but we either will not (lack of resources/priority) or can not (3rd party issues) fix.   We kept track of these issues so we could try and fix them in new releases.  So far we've done this with putting an issue in the "Deferred" state: an issue is deferred to a later time.  However, deferred is an open ticket status.  I have a strong desire to be able to close milestones; it makes it much clearer what we are working on and what not.  This would also allow us to start using Assembla for more than ticket adminstration; we can start using its project management features to have better control over our efforts.

As an example: release 1.1 and 1.5 we are not working on.  Tickets in those milestones will never be worked on again.  Still they remain open.  

What I want is:
- a milestone per release and the ability to close milestones we no longer work on
- a record of known issues per release without those issues remaining open tickets after we've decided we will not work on them for that particular release.

Any change of the policy for dealing with known issues will need to be updated in the ticket status guide https://www.assembla.com/spaces/file_sender/wiki/Ticket_Status_Guide

summary: Establish list of beta and release candidate sites
description:
our release policy states a release candidate will be field-tested on at least two FileSender release candidate test sites:
- Production sites with at least X transfers by X unique users per day.
- The sites run with well-known configurations making what are considered standard features available to their user bases.

for a release candidate to become a production release it needs to have been running production traffic with live users for at least two weeks on at least two release candidate test sites and shown no significant issues impairing service for the users, it can become the production (major) release.

This implies we need at least to FileSEnder release candidate sites.  A site would need to install a release candidate within a certain number of time after release, for example a week.  A release candidate site should typically get a heads up at least 2 weeks in advance before release.

Preferably we would have a similar mechanism for beta testing sites so we get some organised feedback on the quality of a beta.  However, the release candidate sites are more important.

Race condition with file deletion cronjob under certain circumstances
description:
Note: when the quick fix is implemented for 1.5/1.0.1, this ticket should be relabeled to "under development 2.0".

I got a number of user reports about a file upload that went through just fine but the file seemed to be automatically deleted when you tried to download it.  So upload went fine, move went fine, email was sent out, download screen popped up, but download went bad.  Nothing significant in the logging.

After observing what goes on on our system I made these observations: observations:
 
1. on our install the php temp upload directory is set to /tmp rather then to /data/filesender/tmp
2. our FileSender files directory is /data/filesender/files
3. /tmp and /files are on different partitions.  That means that a move is an actual transfer, rather then just flipping a pointer in an inode.
4. our cleanup (expiry) cronjob ran every 5 minutes
 
This means the move from temp dir to filesender files dir takes time. With an 1.5 GB file this might intersect with the cronjob running.  If I read the cronjob's code correctly, it checks for files that do exist in the filestore but do not have a database entry associated with them.  If it founds such files, it deletes them.  In possibly the same cronjob run, it then notices a stale database entry that is then set to "closed".
 
Presto, the file has disappeared for the user.

The problem affects both 1.0.1 and 1.5.  There is a quick fix under discussion, which in practice will prevent the problem from occuring unless you configure your site explicitly to trigger it.  The ultimate solution has to wait for a redo of the database schema in the post-1.5 development work.

cronjob to periodically clean non-anonomised log table
description:
The current log table grows and grows and grows.  

A scheduled periodic cleanup that throws away entries older than <configurable log-retention period> needs to be implemented.  Deployment wise this fits nicely after we have the working anonimizer (part of the statistics module).  That way we can keep the log data relevant for statistics, and throw away the non-anonimised logging.  A default retention period of 6 weeks sounds sane.

A first thought for implementation: make it part of the existing clean-up cronjob (found in filesender/cron/cron.php).  There's already interaction with the database there.  It would save a FileSender admin the hassle of setting up 2 cronjobs.  

Thank you Claude Tompers from RESTENA for reminding us about this one.

summary: mail sending error handling
description:
When the PHP mail() call (in classes/Mail.php) fails (for whatever reason) it returns 'false'. The sendEmail function returns this result to the various callers but that result is not always checked or used for user-feedback. This needs improvement.

- consistently check and use the sendEmail return value 
- do this before logging or reporting a succesfull insert/update/message sent
- log failures somewhere?
- show an error to the user ('Error sending mail, please contact your administrator' ??)

Note that mail() can fail even after a succesfull insert/update so in general the upload/voucher-creation is OK. We might need a more specific message then, for example with a voucher people should create a new one after the administrator has found and fixed the problem. With an upload a resend should be fine in general (unless the problem was caused by the mail-adresses of course).

Candidate for beta2 if 'easy' but I prefer beta3 to get more testing time.

summary: end-to-end File Encryption [XL]
description:
Goal: end-to-end data confidentiality and authenticity.  

Viewing FileSender as a file transport channel, encryption is  preferably done end-to-end, where all data leaves the sender's client encrypted and gets decrypted on the receivers client.  The server should never see plaintext data.  If this is not viable, server-side encryption can be considered to improve "at rest" protection.  Note that the effects are different though:

* Client-side: data is *never* plain text on the server: a server hack would have no influence (provided the javascript served to users isn't changed ;)

* Server-side: data is plain-text on the server until encrypted *after* upload, and plaintext after decryption before download


Important constraints:
-encryption functionality must be possible without provisioning stuff to the user.  The user should be able to use it without installing anything.  This implies it ought to be done using plain javascript.
-encryption functionality must not imply additional server-side infrastructural requirements to f.ex. get a key to a user (sms gateway).  This is nice added functionality, but we must maintain a filesender install that is fully functional with least possible server-side complications
-the encryption key must not be transferred using the same channel as the download link is transferred

It is perfectly acceptable to have this "power funcionality" only work in HTml5 fileAPI supporting browsers

Note that as soon as we have this working, we also need to investigate signed javascript: in the scenario where a FileSender server is hacked, end-users need to be able to rely on the integrity of the javascript code used for encryption.  It looks like this ought to be possible: http://answers.uchicago.edu/page.php?id=19495

summary: PHP configuration Documentation
New feature suggestion: transaction audit trail
description:
Consider an audit trail functionality.

One way to implement this is to show a historical MyFiles.  Disadvantage: requires audit trail data to hang around.  That's contrary our wish to retain least possible sensitive data on the FileSender service.

Another and  possibly easier way: once the transaction expires, wrap the entire transaction history in a PDF and ship it to the sender.  This PDF could be timestamped and signed to provide strength to the audit trail.  

This would be accompanied by a config option that says "always on" or "user override", and in case of the latter would either tick it by default or leave it open by default.  A service admin would need to be able to indicate whether this optoin is part of the standard "always show" options or not.

summary: devise a solution for SPF records
description:
FileSender now sends "there's a file for you" messages *on behalf of* and *with the From: address* of the file uploader.  This will lead to issues for domains that use SPF.  

Some possible ways to deal with this:
-FAQ entry that sites using SPF that want to use this as a service should put the filesender box in their SPF records
-use the FileSender service email address as From:, and put the user's email address in the body of the message.  
-under the assumption that SPF works on SMTP envelope level, use the FileSender service email address as envelope from (rfc2821 MAIL FROM:), email address of  the person sending the file in RFC822 From:

whichever way we choose, seems that some more configurables are needed....

summary: PostgresSQL integer field out of range
description: Date: Fri, 16 Oct 2009 11:57:02 +0200 From: Hans Zandbelt Reply-To: filesender-dev@filesender.org To: filesender-dev@filesender.org Cc: coin-tech@surfnet.nl Subject: [filesender-dev] PostgresSQL integer field out of range Hi, We encounter the following error for large file sizes in Beta 0.1.2: PHP Warning: pg_query() [function.pg-query]: Query failed: ERROR: value "3573778432" is out of range for type integer in /usr/local/simplesamlphp_1_4/www/filesender/fs_main.php on line 291 it looks indeed like the type of the filesize column in the database is plain 32-bits signed "integer" on which the PostgresSQL docs say: integer 4 bytes usual choice for integer -2147483648 to +2147483647 Since filesender is meant to facilitate exchange of large files with positive sizes, I'm sure there exists a better type to suit this behaviour. According to: http://www.postgresql.org/docs/8.0/interactive/datatype.html#DATATYPE-INT there's no such thing as an unsigned long, but bigint 8 bytes large-range integer -9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807 might do a better job. Regards, Hans. -- Hans Zandbelt hans.zandbelt@surfnet.nl SURFnet http://www.surfnet.nl

How to handle multiple email addresses from user's LDAP entry
description:
This was the original issue posted:

======================================================
Date: Thu, 25 Feb 2010 12:46:43 +0100
From: Mario Vandaele <>
To: filesender-dev
Subject: [filesender-dev] LDAP authentication and multiple e-mail address entries in
    "mail" attribute

Hello,

Currently I use LDAP authentication/attributes during my tests.
I use my organisation's ldap server, which contains multiple e-mail address entries for
my "mail" attribute.
The 1st is my office e-mail address, but the others are aliases for distribution lists
within the organisation.
So, whenever I successfully log in, the "From"-field is already filled in with all
entries and also stored as such in "filefrom" in "files" table in db.
As a consequence the receiver of the files gets to see these entries as well, but when
he successfully downloaded the file, then an e-mail is sent to all e-mail entries
(=spam,=confidentiality, =major issue).
So, my suggestion is to make the "From"-field editable, by which I mean that the
parameter value is parsed and a checklist is created with all found e-mail addresses,
so you can tick off the ones you do/don't want to use (at least one selected) and then
stored as such in the db.
======================================================================

We had similar issues in the Confusa project.  Users can have multiple email addresses.

Options the software should have:
   -take first address
   -give user option to pick from addresses (display multiple addresses with checkboxes in front) but require at least one address

in both options the From: field would need to be editable.

We would need a configuration option indicating which of the two the software would use.

how does that sound?

summary: Multi-language email templates [L]
description:
With version 1.5 we have a multi-language UI.  The email templates are still one language.  This might be a problem we can not solve.  

How do you deal with a Norwegian user sending a file to a Brazilian user?  The Brazilian might not want to receive a Norwegian email.  A Norwegian email with "english at the bottom" might also not be desirable.  Letting people set the language of the recipients sounds cumbersome and would be unwieldy with multiple recipients.  

There is no widely deployed mechanism to let an email client pick a locale on behalf of the recipient.  

So this problem appears to be a thorny one: we know who the *sender* is, but have no clue about the receiver.  The user knows but shouldn't be bothered with questions about that and besides, allowing a user to set a certain attribute of a recipient stimulates the next desire: being able to store such information about recipients.  We currently store no permanent information whatsoever and that makes the service very easy to run, which is a characteristic we should think carefully about before giving it up.

summary: Overhaul log mechanism
description: Logging is done at two places at the moment.  Logging goes into log files and logging goes into a database.  I would say that both are needed.  Logging to log files makes it easy for a sysadmin to investigate faults in the service.  Logging to the database means that a service manager can easily generate custom reports and stats without bothering the sysadmin.  But, this needs a thorough rethink for 2.0 so we have some solid and consistent thinking behind our logging mechanism: clear goals for what needs to be achieved that will lead to a clear implementation of logging and loglevels as well as what is logged where (when).

summary: email address unsuitable as GUID
description:
We use the email address as the GUID.  That means that if you can get your CEOs email address
in your IdP entry, you have full access to his files on FileSender.

Up until now that didn't matter because well, you could see what files he had there.  Then we added
the capability to delete.  Still didn't matter, but opened for DoS.  But from beta-1.10, you can
add new recipients to existing uploads.  And then it matters.  Inadvertent data disclosure sucks.

We're thinking it should be solvable by not using email address but ePPN and/or
eduPersonTargetedId.

After some discussion probably what needs to be done is:
-add GUID=eduPersontargetedId attribute mapping to config file
-use this GUID as the GUID in the app throughout

Note: we really should think of a way to still be able to use OpenId as well?

summary: improve feedback when log directory is missing
description:
When the log directory is missing, or can't be written to, the flash application loads but doesn't display a login button or the splash text.  It's fairly easy to debug *once you look in the PHP logging*.  Even then, the error reported there requires you to either understand what's going on or dive in the code to figure out exactly which file/directory is missing.  That can be done better.

It would be really good if the FileSender app has a better sanity check when starting up, and actually reports back.  In the case of a missing log directory, I guess the sane thing to do is to report this through the UI.  So giving some sane feedback where an admin can read it.

Thinking a bit more.  Usually you want all error logging to go to the error log.  There are two things in particular that can not be logged to the error log.

1. config file parsing error
2. logfile not writable

These two circumstances should simply be reported through the UI?

[Thu Jun 17 16:30:59 2010] [error] [client 158.38.62.126] File does not exist: /var/www/filesender/www/files/null0148.JPG

The bug is actually two issues:

2. the missing error message to the user about the server side error.

summary: gears upload tmpfile handling
description:
The gears upload uses the tmpfiles directory to store the uploaded chunks under the 'orignal filename'. When two separate users/sessions are uploading a file with the same filename the chunks are added to a single file in the tmpfiles directory. This leads a.o. to corrupt files and information leakage. Solution would be to use a unique (user-dependent?) identifier (either a subdir or prefix for the filename).

How to reproduce (at least on 0.1.13 and 0.1.14): 

take two *different* files (reasonably large so that it takes a while to upload) and give them the same name (i.e. testfile.tst). Have two users (or 1 user and two separate browsers/machine) upload the file (one user/browser one of the two files, the other user/browser the other) at the same time. Compare the resulting files after upload (check size and md5sum).

Users want to know *when* their file is actually thrown away.

Come to think of it: rather then deleting we might want to advise proper 'secure deletion' of a file to make sure no remnants remain.

summary: Detailed transaction logging facility per user
description:
At the moment when something goes wrong with a file upload we have insufficient information to figure out where in the client or in the server the problem might be.  It's difficult to ask the person with the problem to tell us what went wrong where, reproduce it etc.  Better it would be to have proper logging.  

To solve this we can implement client-side step-by-step logging that sends a log line to the server for every 'processing step' the client takes.  Server side it would result in one logfile per user.  Preferably with the username in the filename to make debugging for the server admin easy.  The logging would be switched on/off from the server side.  Server side a filter based on ePTID would select for which users logging would be maintained.  That way you wouldn't get too much of logging on a busy server.  

The logging would have to log both the client side steps and the server side steps for that particular user in 1 integrated logfile.

If we have this in the code then even though sometimes things wouldn't work, we at least have a solid handle on where something went wrong.   






Different combinations of operating system (version) - browser (version)  - flash version have different results and it's difficult to pinpoint exactly what piece of code was responsible for stuff going wrong.  

To solve this functionality needs to be imp

summary: Outdated files in database that misses from disk halts system while removing outdated files

 if (file_exists($FilestoreDirectory."/".ensureSaneFileUid($row["fileuid"]).sanitizeFilename($row["fileoriginalname"]))) {

summary: 4GB download limit on Windows ??
description:
When downloading large files (larger than 4GB) on Windows (XP or Win7) with various browsers (FF, Opera, Chrome) the downloads essentially seem to fail on a strange 4GB limit in Flash or the Flash app. Symptoms are:

- download starts and a temporary file FlashTmp0.tmp is created
- FlashTmp0.tmp grows while downloading
- at around 2G downloaded bytes the progress counter 'hangs' (see #255) but the file keeps growing
- at exactly 4GB (4294967296 bytes) the FlashTmp0.tmp stops growing
- the download itself (network traffic) continues
- after the download has finished (i.e. network traffic stops) the display still shows the counter.and the cancel button. Pressing cancel removes the FlashTmp0.tmp file.

Note that the disk/filesystem used to save the download and where the FlashTmp0.tmp is stored is capable of storing large files (> 4GB), better yet, the files larger than 4GB were created on and uploaded from the same filesyetem, downloading the file directly to the disk/filesystem (with a https:.../files/... from the browser) gets you the complete file. 

This appears to be a Windows-specific problem, the same large files are downloaded OK on Mac and Linux. Symptoms are seen by at least two independent users (Jan and me) but it might be a good idea if others could try a download of a 4GB+ file on Windows and see what happens (note: don't use IE8, see #249)

summary: optimizing config.php for distribution
description:
At the moment there is a problem when the default config.php is changed, the debian package process patches config.php to set default settings and if this file is changed the patch fails.

There are a number of solutions;
 * leave it as is; make the patch every time config.php changes
 * Split out config directives into separated files (DB config, location config, etc), this minimizes the chance of change collision
 * Include a complete copy of config.php in the debian package. Problem here is that if config.php is changed the debian version needs to be revised also.

Probably we will have the same problem for the RPM packages.

- Upload took more than the session duration time (this probably can be
